Big Fat Myths","description":"

Weight loss fads in the form of diets and exercise regimes (with mostly unrealistic claims) are ubiquitous in modern day life; however, there is surprising ignorance and confusion about how we lose weight, with most people unable to answer the simplest question: when you lose weight, where does the fat go? Popular (incorrect) answers include energy, heat, faeces and sweat. Surprisingly, this question has also baffled health professionals including general practitioners, dietitians and professional trainers.


This course will lift the veil on weight loss by tracing every atom you eat into and out of your body, and you will learn the fate of fat during weight loss, that is, it is converted to carbon dioxide and water and exits your body mainly through your lungs. Along the way, you will also learn how humans convert foods into useful energy, what exactly is happening in your bodies during weight loss and weight gain, and by the end you will be able to critically examine popular weight loss claims as well as your own diet and lifestyle. Diet myths and wellness nonsense topple like dominoes along the way.


No prior scientific knowledge is assumed as we aim to provide you with the knowledge to answer this big, fat myth.

contentlets.description:
Weight loss fads in the form of diets and exercise regimes (with mostly unrealistic claims) are ubiquitous in modern day life; however, there is surprising ignorance and confusion about how we lose weight, with most people unable to answer the simplest question: when you lose weight, where does the fat go? Popular (incorrect) answers include energy, heat, faeces and sweat. Surprisingly, this question has also baffled health professionals including general practitioners, dietitians and professional trainers.

This course will lift the veil on weight loss by tracing every atom you eat into and out of your body, and you will learn the fate of fat during weight loss, that is, it is converted to carbon dioxide and water and exits your body mainly through your lungs. Along the way, you will also learn how humans convert foods into useful energy, what exactly is happening in your bodies during weight loss and weight gain, and by the end you will be able to critically examine popular weight loss claims as well as your own diet and lifestyle. Diet myths and wellness nonsense topple like dominoes along the way.

No prior scientific knowledge is assumed as we aim to provide you with the knowledge to answer this big, fat myth.

Since the release of the first human genome about two decades ago, our understanding of genetics has improved significantly. Facilitated by massive developments in DNA sequencing technologies, we now live in a society where genetics and genomics, and applications thereof, have become household terms. We hear about genetically modified food crops with extra nutrients or drought resistance, and personalised medicine offers new hope (or hype) in health care. Genetic tools are routinely used in forensics and gene doping is a growing concern at sporting events. Synthetic biology promises new frontiers of technology, and the day we use DNA for data storage is not that far away.


What does this all mean? Is it ethical? Is it legal? What are the social implications that come with these applications?


This interactive, fully online course will introduce students to fundamental genetic concepts using real life applications and implications of genetics while providing an opportunity to get hands-on experience in analysing and interpreting genetic data. Students will be encouraged to critically evaluate the ethical, legal and social implications of genetic advances throughout the course. On completion, we anticipate the students will be better prepared to survive in the “genome generation” and participate in informed debate and decision making with regard to incorporating genetic interventions in everyday life.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"09963dfc1b426410d5fb0fabdc4bcb75","name":"Fully online - "},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Practical report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"25","description":"

The online practical component of the course requires students to analyse a set of DNA sequencing results and answer a series of questions based on their observations. This task will assess their ability to follow the scientific method to investigate a real-life problem using DNA technologies and their ability to interpret the results obtained. Students will be introduced to the task in Week 1 and will run throughout the whole term with the final report due in Week 10.  Students will need to submit their reports via Turnitin and feedback will be provided individually.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d1963dfc1b426410d5fb0fabdc4bcb78","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d9963dfc1b426410d5fb0fabdc4bcb78","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5d963dfc1b426410d5fb0fabdc4bcbd7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Discussion forum","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

This task aims to assess the ability of students to develop an evidence-based argument around the ethical, legal and social implications of genetics applications and interventions. There will be a discussion forum for each module (each week), and students will be required to make a minimum of two posts per week; a post responding to a question set by the course convenor and a response to a post made by another student. The forums will be facilitated and monitored by the course convenors and a rubric will be provided on how the blog posts will be assessed. Five posts selected at random at the end of the term for each student will be assessed. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c5963dfc1b426410d5fb0fabdc4bcb76","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d1963dfc1b426410d5fb0fabdc4bcb77","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d9963dfc1b426410d5fb0fabdc4bcb77","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"91963dfc1b426410d5fb0fabdc4bcbd1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Weekly quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

These quizzes will focus on the genetic concepts and applications covered during the week and will be held each week except in Week 6 (flexi week). The quizzes will be available online via Moodle Quiz and will consist of 10 multiple-choice or short answer type questions and students will be allowed to attempt the quiz once only. There will be a time limit for the quizzes to prevent students from consulting any reference material. The time allowed should be ample for them to read and answer all the questions. Feedback will be released via Moodle Quiz once the students have completed each quiz.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"d9963dfc1b426410d5fb0fabdc4bcb77","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"d9963dfc1b426410d5fb0fabdc4bcb78","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d5963dfc1b426410d5fb0fabdc4bcbdb","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical review","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

This task aims to assess the ability of students to identify genetic applications and interventions as reported in media and apply basic genetic theories and concepts learnt in the course to evaluate how they are represented in the media. Students will be provided with a list of media articles or documentaries where real-life scenarios of genetics applications or interventions are discussed. Students will choose one application or intervention and prepare a critical review on how the application or intervention is presented in the media. Students can choose to present the critical review in a written essay or in a video. This assignment is due in Week 7 and feedback will be provided via Moodle (Turnitin).

Molecules, Cells and Genes","description":"

The course is concerned with the basic characteristics of all life. The chemistry of life is examined, with emphasis on the ways in which living things construct and break down macromolecules. The way in which the genetic code controls these processes depends to a great extent on the structure and function of cell components, and cell biology is a major component of the course. The final topic is genetics - the way in which the genetic code is inherited and the ways in which it can be modified.

There will be 4 parts to this project:

  • Essay (15%): students will be asked to prepare and submit the individual essay 
  • Pitch (5%): this is a team presentation 
  • Presentation (15%): this is the final team presentation where students are asked to further develop/ elevate their presentation by utilising the peer feedback received in the pitch. 
  • Portfolio (5%): this is a documentation of team meetings including ideas discussed, roles of the team member, decisions made, and other notes on the presentation design and execution.

Applied Biomolecular Sciences","description":"

This course provides an overview of the application of molecular and cellular biology to the fields of medicine, plant and animal science, and food, marine and environmental sciences. It draws comparisons between contemporary and conventional technologies through the introduction of traditional and recombinant genetics, microbiology, biochemistry and fermentation engineering in the context of their contribution to the industrial application of biological systems.

Note: Prior to Semester 1, 2014 this course was known as BIOT1011.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"81aa7883db7fa450fe4b322af49619de","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8daa7883db7fa450fe4b322af49619df","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8daa7883db7fa450fe4b322af49619e0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"19aa7883db7fa450fe4b322af49619f6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Literature review","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

Students will complete a literature review related to course material. This will be supported by in-class instructions and online material (on how to undertake a literature review, database use and referencing) and Smart Thinking will be recommended to students.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"85aa7883db7fa450fe4b322af49619df","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"85aa7883db7fa450fe4b322af49619e0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"51aa7883db7fa450fe4b322af49619fb","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Mid-term test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

A 40 multiple choice question test mid-term that covers lecture and laboratory content.

Mark and feedback will be released online in Moodle. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8daa7883db7fa450fe4b322af49619df","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"8daa7883db7fa450fe4b322af49619e0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"59aa7883db7fa450fe4b322af49619fd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Pre-lab quiz and Post-lab review","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will undertake weekly online pre-lab quizzes and conduct post-lab reviews. These include: 

  • Pre-lab quizzes in preparation for laboratory classes
  • A submitted experimental design for the laboratory project
  • Experimental results and discussions (after each practical class) 

The online quizzes on Moodle will be graded and automated feedback provided online. Personalised feedback on the laboratory project design and the experimental results and discussion will be provided online and in-class by demonstrators.

contentlets.description:
This course provides an overview of the application of molecular and cellular biology to the fields of medicine, plant and animal science, and food, marine and environmental sciences. It draws comparisons between contemporary and conventional technologies through the introduction of traditional and recombinant genetics, microbiology, biochemistry and fermentation engineering in the context of their contribution to the industrial application of biological systems.

Note: Prior to Semester 1, 2014 this course was known as BIOT1011.
contentlets.title: Applied Biomolecular Sciences

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"BABS2011","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BABS2011 - Current Trends in Biotechnology","description":"

Through case study presentations students will be introduced to how biotechnology advances are impacting on society by solving problems in medicine, agriculture, and environmental management. Lectures discuss current analytical technologies that are enabling the performance of scientific fundamental and applied research. Through assignments, students will be provided with the opportunities to develop scientific expertise in a biotechnology targeted area of their interest and to develop the skills required to interpret scientific findings and report them to key technical and non-technical stakeholders involved in biotechnology commercialisation.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c3029f23db35d850eb6b147a3a9619fc","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"30","description":"

There are two parts to this project: 

  • Project plan (10%)
  • Technical report (20%) 

For the project plan, feedback will be provided during the class discussion in week 4 and for the technical report, feedback will be provided via Moodle with rubric comments in week 7. 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"32029f23db35d850eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"22029f23db35d850eb6b147a3a9619d1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Quizzes","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

There will be two quizzes during the term, each worth 20%. 

Quiz 1 will cover lecture material delivered in weeks 1-5. Feedback will be provided in week 7. 

Quiz 2 will cover lecture material covered in weeks 6-9. Feedback will be provided in week 10.

There are two components to this assignment:

  • Literature Review (20%) - feedback will be provided online in Moodle with rubric comments in week 9.
  • Presentation (10%) - peer assessment, instant feedback will be given verbally during the discussion class.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"BABS2202","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BABS2202 - Molecular Cell Biology 1","description":"

Cells are not only the basic building blocks of all organisms they are also the source of the vast diversity that characterizes life on earth. This course provides an opportunity to explore the nature of cells, both the unity and the breadth of cell structure and function, from prokaryote to eukaryotes. It builds on the introduction contained in BABS1201. The major topics covered include: the cell cycle and the processes that regulate entry into, transition through and exit from the cycle; mitosis, meiosis, cyclins and cdks, apoptosis and cancer; cellular integrity and movement; interactions of cells with each other and their environment, signaling pathways, immunology, chemotaxis and sensing, biofilm formation and interactions between prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. Practical work illustrates and extends the lectures. Tutorials are designed to reinforce the lecture material and to emphasize the development of writing skills, group work and the process of scientific enquiry.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5bde4a0ddbffac10fe4b322af4961963","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Final Theory Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"35","description":"

A written examination will cover all the lecture content other than what was assessed in the mid-term exam. This will consist of multiple choice, short answer and essay-style questions. 

Mark/grade will be released to students on official assessment results release date. Individual feedback will be provided upon request. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"17de4a0ddbffac10fe4b322af4961967","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"17de4a0ddbffac10fe4b322af4961969","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":"Group","value":"Group"},"assessment_name":"Group Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

A group of 3-4 students will be asked to develop a game that teaches a concept learned in this course. There are two parts to this assessment: 

  • Group (10%): an oral presentation to describe the designed game including an instruction on how to play the game and how the cell biology material learned in BABS2202 is delivered
  • Individual (5%): a written documentation briefing the underlying science behind this project

Group presentation will be marked by their demonstrator as well as their peers. Instant feedback will be provided verbally after the presentations. 

Individual assessment task will be marked by the course coordinator or demonstrators. Mark/grade will be released online and written feedback will be provided.

A written examination consisting of both multiple choice and short answer questions. This assessment will cover all practical contents delivered throughout the term. 

This assessment task will be marked by the course coordinator or demonstrators. Mark will be released online and feedback will be given upon request.

A written examination consisting of both multiple choice and short answer questions. This assessment will cover material delivered in weeks 1-4. 

This assessment will be marked by the course coordinator and the feedback will be given in person during a Large Group Tutorial (LGT).

Genetics is the study of inheritance and is an exciting and rapidly expanding discipline with applications in medicine, biotechnology, agriculture and many other fields. This course provides an overview of the key concepts in genetics including gene structure and transmission, genetic variation, regulation of gene activity, genetic variation, mutation and evolution. Laboratory experiments and conference-style activities are used to demonstrate genetic theory and its application, and provide an introduction to real-world research in genetics.


Assumed knowledge: CHEM1011 Chemistry A: Atoms, Molecules and Energy or BIOS1101 Evolutionary and Functional Biology.


Note: Prior to Semester 1, 2014 this course was known as BIOS2021.

Genetics is the study of inheritance and is an exciting and rapidly expanding discipline with applications in medicine, biotechnology, agriculture and many other fields. This course provides an overview of the key concepts in genetics including gene structure and transmission, genetic variation, regulation of gene activity, genetic variation, mutation and evolution. Laboratory experiments and conference-style activities are used to demonstrate genetic theory and its application, and provide an introduction to real-world research in genetics. The course includes self-directed experiments and extended presentations on the scientific literature, and is designed for high-achieving students interested in a research career.


Assumed knowledge: CHEM1011 Chemistry A: Atoms, Molecules and Energy or BIOS1101 Evolutionary and Functional Biology.


Note: Prior to Semester 1, 2014 this course was known as BIOS2621.

contentlets.description:
Genetics is the study of inheritance and is an exciting and rapidly expanding discipline with applications in medicine, biotechnology, agriculture and many other fields. This course provides an overview of the key concepts in genetics including gene structure and transmission, genetic variation, regulation of gene activity, genetic variation, mutation and evolution. Laboratory experiments and conference-style activities are used to demonstrate genetic theory and its application, and provide an introduction to real-world research in genetics. The course includes self-directed experiments and extended presentations on the scientific literature, and is designed for high-achieving students interested in a research career.

Assumed knowledge: CHEM1011 Chemistry A: Atoms, Molecules and Energy or BIOS1101 Evolutionary and Functional Biology.

Note: Prior to Semester 1, 2014 this course was known as BIOS2621.

This course provides a broad coverage of material describing the fundamentals of microbial genetics. It is intended for students interested in microbiology, molecular biology and genetics. The course covers fundamentally important and well-established concepts in microbial genetics, while emphasising the latest discoveries that have emerged from contemporary research efforts in the field (presented by senior researchers). Topics may include genetics of bacteriophages, bacteria, archaea and yeast, mutation and evolution, mechanisms of gene transfer, gene regulation and adaptive responses, and genomics and functional genomics of individual microorganisms and whole microbial communities. The practical component includes contemporary wet-lab microbial genetics experiments that complement lecture material. The practical component also emphasises interaction between demonstrators and students, facilitated through a rich variety of concept tutorials that cover diverse topics. These topics may include transposon mutagenesis, gene library construction, gene complementation using recombinant plasmids, gene expression and regulation studies, UV mutagenesis and DNA repair, restriction/modification systems, promoter rescue experiments, and a variety of gene exchange techniques. The socioeconomic impact of microbial genetics is also discussed in student presentations. An advanced version of BABS3021 is also offered: MICR3621 Microbial Genetics (Advanced). MICR3621 differs from BABS3021 in that it incorporates unique advanced features in both the practical component and report assignment.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"129e2e40db576c10fe4b322af496198c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":"Individual","value":"Individual"},"assessment_name":"Practical Report ","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

The practical report is based on experiments students performed in the laboratory.  The report will mimic the draft/manuscript of a published paper. Students will be assessed on the quality of the content and presentation in each section of the report (Aim, Introduction, Methods, Results, Discussion, References). The report will also include a log of laboratory activities which will be assessed on the degree of engagement with the practical activities. Feedback will be given electronically by instructors using a marking rubric.

The midterm exam will cover lecture material delivered in the first half of the course (weeks 1-5). The exam will test understanding of the lecture material. It will be marked by the course instructors and feedback will be given during the practicals and/or lecture review sessions.

Students will deliver a presentation to their practical discussion group. Integrating knowledge from different sources in microbial genetics, the students are expected to critically evaluate scientific findings and perspectives to synthesise ethical, social or professional issues pertaining to the field. Students will be assessed on the appropriateness and quality of the content and on their ability to communicate effectively.  Feedback will be given online by instructors and fellow students using a marking rubric.

contentlets.keywords: biotechnology & biomolecular sciences,biotechnology and biomolecular science,microbial genetics
contentlets.description: This course provides a broad coverage of material describing the fundamentals of microbial genetics. It is intended for students interested in microbiology, molecular biology and genetics. The course covers fundamentally important and well-established concepts in microbial genetics, while emphasising the latest discoveries that have emerged from contemporary research efforts in the field (presented by senior researchers). Topics may include genetics of bacteriophages, bacteria, archaea and yeast, mutation and evolution, mechanisms of gene transfer, gene regulation and adaptive responses, and genomics and functional genomics of individual microorganisms and whole microbial communities. The practical component includes contemporary wet-lab microbial genetics experiments that complement lecture material. The practical component also emphasises interaction between demonstrators and students, facilitated through a rich variety of concept tutorials that cover diverse topics. These topics may include transposon mutagenesis, gene library construction, gene complementation using recombinant plasmids, gene expression and regulation studies, UV mutagenesis and DNA repair, restriction/modification systems, promoter rescue experiments, and a variety of gene exchange techniques. The socioeconomic impact of microbial genetics is also discussed in student presentations. An advanced version of BABS3021 is also offered: MICR3621 Microbial Genetics (Advanced). MICR3621 differs from BABS3021 in that it incorporates unique advanced features in both the practical component and report assignment.
contentlets.title: Microbial Genetics

Biotechnology and Bioengineering","description":"

In order to bring new biotechnology products to the market, scalable bioprocesses must be developed and validated. This course covers the bioprocessing and economic principles involved in the operation, development and design of large-scale biotechnology-based processes. It includes analysis of fermentation kinetics, batch and continuous modes of operation, bioprocess optimisation, principles of fermentor scale up, downstream processing and bioprocess design, as well as principles of economic feasibility analysis. Selected bioprocesses will be used to develop an understanding of fundamental bioprocessing principles, including process scale-up. Examples will be drawn from major biotechnology sectors, including biofuels, biopharmaceutical manufacture and manufacture of other bioproducts from bacterial, yeast and mammalian hosts. Laboratory sessions and problem-solving tutorials (including computer-based classes) will supplement lecture material. At least one detailed case study will be undertaken by students which will investigate economic and technical feasibility of a bioprocess.

The course convenor will mark this assignment and written feedback will be provided.

There are two parts to this assignment: 

  1. Define the biorefinery concept 
  2. Understand and Explain one of the biorefinery concepts given in part 1

Full detail will be provided in the course manual and (or) Moodle site. 

The course convenor will mark this assignment and written feedback will be returned to students.

Immunology","description":"

BABS3041 provides a broad coverage of immunology. The course is for students majoring in Medical Microbiology, Biotechnology, Biomolecular Science, Medical Science and other areas related to human health who are interested in gaining knowledge in Immunology. The course will first introduce the multiple components of the immune system, their functions, interactions and regulations during immune responses. Then the applied and clinical aspects of immunology will be introduced, including allergy, immunodeficiency, immune system and cancer, vaccination, autoimmunity, engineering antibodies, diagnostic immunology and immunological research strategies. The practical program introduces students to critical immunological techniques such as immune cell stimulation, immunological assays and flow cytometry. The course also introduces students to critical evaluation of immunological issues of community importance and literature.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"BABS3061","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BABS3061 - Medical Biotechnology","description":"

Biotechnology innovation is in a large part driven by the requirement for improvements in medical diagnosis and therapy for a range of diseases including autoimmune diseases, diseases of inflammation and cancer, and infectious diseases. Innovations in biomolecular therapies such as recombinant proteins, monoclonal antibodies, stem cells and novel bioinspired materials have and will continue to improve available medical treatments for many conditions. The course is designed to give students a detailed insight into the principles and techniques leading to these innovations. The practical work includes production of a recombinant monoclonal antibody fragment, and pre-clinical assessment of its diagnostic and therapeutic potential.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"41dd79a7db359850eb6b147a3a9619df","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Lab Book","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

Students must maintain the lab book throughout the practical class, The lab book should contain a detailed record of all experimental procedures, observations and results obtained in the practical class. 

Continuous formative feedback will be provided in the practical classes. 

Marks and feedback will be provided in the last practical class in week 10. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"70dd79a7db359850eb6b147a3a9619cc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"20dd79a7db359850eb6b147a3a9619ac","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

The exam will cover the lecture material delivered in weeks 5-11. The exam will consist of an essay-style question. 

Mark/grade will be released to students on official assessment results release date. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"bcdd79a7db359850eb6b147a3a9619ce","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"68dd79a7db359850eb6b147a3a9619b0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Literature Review","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

This is a 2,500-word reviews on recent approaches to cancer immunotherapy using monoclonal antibodies and their fragments. 

Marks with written and verbal feedback will be provided in the practical class in week 5. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f4dd79a7db359850eb6b147a3a9619c6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"acdd79a7db359850eb6b147a3a9619a2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Journal Article","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

At the end of the practical, students will write the work in the format of a scientific journal article suitable for publication in Microbiology. 

Marks with written and verbal feedback will be provided in the practical class in week 10.

contentlets.description: NOTE: Up to Session 1 2010 this course was offered as BIOT3071. From Session 2 2010 it has been changed to course code BABS3071. This course is an introduction to the commercialisation of biotechnology. It covers important aspects of biotechnology that are critical in the industry. This includes funding for biotechnology R&D (corporate and government), intellectual property (IP), commercialisation strategies and regulatory issues. Expert speakers who work in the biotechnology industry present most of the lectures. Assignments include a stock market game and detailed case studies on Australian biotechnology companies, including those that are developing new drugs, diagnostics and devices.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"BABS3081","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BABS3081 - Bacteria and Disease","description":"

Bacteria and Disease aims to provide students with a high level of understanding of the pathogenic mechanisms used by a diverse array of bacterial pathogens to cause human disease. In addition, the epidemiology and strategies used to control and prevent these infectious diseases will be discussed.   The lecture program will include key pathogens infecting different body systems.  In conjunction with the lecture program, the laboratory program will provide students with practical experience in contemporary medical microbiology techniques used for the diagnosis of bacterial infections. In addition, students will develop their research skills by conducting a research project on the isolation and characterisation of a common bacterial pathogen using conventional and molecular techniques.

The objective of the course is to provide students with the skills and knowledge required to identify and pursue business opportunities based on technological discovery.   During lectures and workshops, students will be introduced to productisation; commercialisation strategy; market research and benchmarking; government, private equity and public market funding options; due diligence; business principles; human resources; budgeting; valuation; and financial accounting.   The accounting component of the course will involve prescribed textbook readings and the weekly completion and submission of assessable homework exercises. The major assignment, which will be facilitated during class, will involve the small team preparation and pitching of start-up business plans for the commercialisation of technology based opportunities.   Students will be able to join teams working on plans relating to their developing professional background. They will also be encouraged to source potential opportunities relating to their own research and prospective career interests.  The business planning process will bring together all components of the course content with students developing an understanding of how science, technology and business are integrated and interdependent in industry and they will gain insight into the need for all professions (including scientists!) within a technology-based company to understand business imperatives and metrics if the company is to be a success.


NOTE: Up to Session 1 2010 this course was offered as BIOT3091. From Session 2 2010 it has been changed to course code BABS3091.

contentlets.description:
The objective of the course is to provide students with the skills and knowledge required to identify and pursue business opportunities based on technological discovery.   During lectures and workshops, students will be introduced to productisation; commercialisation strategy; market research and benchmarking; government, private equity and public market funding options; due diligence; business principles; human resources; budgeting; valuation; and financial accounting.   The accounting component of the course will involve prescribed textbook readings and the weekly completion and submission of assessable homework exercises. The major assignment, which will be facilitated during class, will involve the small team preparation and pitching of start-up business plans for the commercialisation of technology based opportunities.   Students will be able to join teams working on plans relating to their developing professional background. They will also be encouraged to source potential opportunities relating to their own research and prospective career interests.  The business planning process will bring together all components of the course content with students developing an understanding of how science, technology and business are integrated and interdependent in industry and they will gain insight into the need for all professions (including scientists!) within a technology-based company to understand business imperatives and metrics if the company is to be a success.

NOTE: Up to Session 1 2010 this course was offered as BIOT3091. From Session 2 2010 it has been changed to course code BABS3091.

contentlets.description: The syllabus comprises a detailed analysis of gene structure and function which includes: structure and properties of polynucleotides such as DNA and RNA; structure of chromatin; mechanisms and regulation of gene replication, transcription and translation, DNA repair and the molecular biology of cancer induction; recombinant DNA technology; nulceic acid sequencing, ecombinant DNA technology, application of genomics and proteomics, microarray analyses; protein production using recombinant DNA systems. Practical work provides extensive experience with contemporary molecular techniques; literature surveys and web-based research are also used to enhance the theoretical and practical aspects of the syllabus.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"BABS3151","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BABS3151 - Human Molecular Genetics and Disease","description":"

Personal genomics is revolutionising medicine. Soon, everyone in Australia is likely to have their genome sequenced at birth. What does this mean for how we see ourselves and treat disease? Is our future written in our genes, or can we influence and control our genetic destiny? This course explores the central principles and applications of understanding our genetic makeup and how this is transforming biomedical science. Core concepts and methods in molecular genetics will be introduced and applied to variety of topics on human evolution, development and disease. Students will examine the roles of “nature” versus “nurture”, including epigenetic regulation, and learn how developments in genome technology are opening new avenues for personalised medicine. Lectures and tutorials will be supported by laboratory and bioinformatics practicals using modern research methods and data. Skills developed during these practicals will provide excellent training for any students considering an Honours project in molecular bioscience.

contentlets.keywords: biotechnology & biomolecular sciences,biotechnology and biomolecular science,bioinformatics,genetics,genomics,human genetics,medicine,disease,biomedical science,cancer genomics
contentlets.description: Personal genomics is revolutionising medicine. Soon, everyone in Australia is likely to have their genome sequenced at birth. What does this mean for how we see ourselves and treat disease? Is our future written in our genes, or can we influence and control our genetic destiny? This course explores the central principles and applications of understanding our genetic makeup and how this is transforming biomedical science. Core concepts and methods in molecular genetics will be introduced and applied to variety of topics on human evolution, development and disease. Students will examine the roles of “nature” versus “nurture”, including epigenetic regulation, and learn how developments in genome technology are opening new avenues for personalised medicine. Lectures and tutorials will be supported by laboratory and bioinformatics practicals using modern research methods and data. Skills developed during these practicals will provide excellent training for any students considering an Honours project in molecular bioscience.
contentlets.title: Human Molecular Genetics and Disease

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"BABS3200","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BABS3200 - Synthetic Biology","description":"

Synthetic biology is the design and construction of novel biological systems or the redesign of existing biological systems. A fundamental aim of synthetic biology is to make biology easier to engineer through the application of engineering principles and standardisation of biological components. Central to this engineering is the deconstruction of biological systems into components (e.g. DNA, enzymes, genetic circuits, metabolic pathways, etc.) that can be uncoupled from each other, abstracted into predictable forms, characterised, and reassembled into novel functional systems to solve specific problems.


This course will give students insight into the assembly and design of interchangable biological parts that form the basis of synthetic biology. Students will learn the methods for standardised assembly of DNA and genes into functioning devices, including biological circuits, DNA/RNA/protein nanostructures, and engineered organisms. A particular emphasis is placed on using online tutorials and computer labs to apply engineering principles for the design of a biological system, followed by wet labs to build and evaluate the biological function of the assemblages. This design - build - test paradigm reinforces an understanding of how biological systems are not static processes to be memorised, but rather, dynamic systems which can be manipulated and built from the ground-up.

  • The hands-on building of biological systems is central to the teaching of synthetic biology.
  • Wet lab practicals will reinforce the Design - Build - Test paradigm of synthetic biology.
  • The practicals will be divided into modules that will begin by a computational design aspect, e.g. design and annotation of a gene circuit in a computer lab.
  • Students will subsequently build the design in wet labs and measure a result/output.
  • Practicals will be assessed by submitted reports.
  • Continuous feedback to students as they will submit ~5 reports throughout practical component.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"BABS3281","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"BABS3281 - Molecular Frontiers","description":"

This course focuses on molecular biology techniques commonly used in biomedical research. Using examples from the research performed in the School of BABS, students will gain a practical experience with cloning techniques, cell culture, Western blotting, genotyping, RNA interference, next-generation sequencing, including Illumina and nanopore platforms, and statistical data analysis. The practical laboratory sessions will be supported by lectures presenting examples of biomedical research in the field of cholesterol metabolism, cancer, drug discovery, protein methylation and long non-coding RNA expression. This course is an excellent opportunity for students to acquire skills essential for successful completion of an Honours project.

This course covers cutting edge concepts in genetics, genomics and evolution: genome structure (how genes are organised into genomes), genomics (genome sequencing, assembly and annotation), genome variation and the forces that shape it (mutation, recombination and genetic drift), molecular phylogenetics (capturing and using patterns of evolution), and applications of genomics (conservation genomics, host-pathogen interactions, genome engineering, and systems biology). Multiple aspects of genome biology will be studied and integrated to understand how genomes function and evolve. Core concepts and methods in genomics, molecular evolution and population genetics will be supported by an integrated set of tutorials, science communication tasks and bioinformatics analysis. Modern research methods will be applied to the study and annotation of draft genome assemblies for two venomous Australian snakes (the mainland tiger snake and eastern brown snake), which were sequenced by UNSW at the Ramaciotti Centre for Genomics using the latest sequencing technologies.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"39e7a17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Genome Paper Blog","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

AIM: Effectively communicate original research to a lay audience.

TASK: Write a brief blog post about a published journal article that reports the sequencing of a new genome. Which organism was sequenced and why? What were the methods and technologies used? What state was the final genome? What interesting things did the genome reveal?

SUBMISSION: Blog posts will be submitted through Moodle. The blog post can be entered directly into a Moodle object or attached as a PDF. The primary paper should also be attached as a PDF. A text-only version must be submitted via a separate Turnitin assignment for plagiarism checking. The blog must be a maximum of 700 words with 1-3 images/videos (Sources cited) in submitted as a Moodle object, or two pages if submitted as a PDF. Use the media, e.g. hyperlinks to external webpages or resources.

ASSESSMENT: Each blog post will be assessed under four criteria:

  1. Clarity
    • Is the writing style clear?
    • Is the article well structured?
  2. Content
    • Is the post informative/educational?
    • Is it accurate?
  3. Presentation
    • Are pictures/videos/media well used?
    • Are sources adequately cited/acknowledged?
  4. Interest
    • Did the post tell an interesting story?

Each element will be rated on a scale of 1 (Very Poor) to 5 (Excellent):

  1. Very poor. No redeeming features.
  2. Poor. Some effort made but falls short of meeting the brief.
  3. OK. Enough to pass but not very impressive.
  4. Good. Clear effort made. Not perfect but some impressive features. Good enough to publish online with some minor edits.
  5. Very Good. Of sufficient quality to be published online without change.

Each student will peer mark 5 other randomly-allocated students. Peer marks will be based on the mean total grade given, excluding the highest and lowest marks. The final grade will be the mean of the peer and staff marks.

FEEDBACK: Feedback is provided via the marking rubric. Peer and demonstrator markers are also requested to provide some free-text feedback on the best aspects of the posts, plus where there is room for improvement.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"61e7a17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a9e7a17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"51e7a17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Molecular Evolution Practical","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"25","description":"

AIM: Learn how to apply common bioinformatics tools to study molecular evolution.

TASK: The main coursework for BABS3291 is a term-long online bioinformatics practical, supported by computer labs and Moodle lessons. In the first part of the practical, students will work through step-by-step guides to different molecular evolution analyses. Emphasis will be on understanding the core principles from lectures, and developing transferable bioinformatics skills through exposure to a variety of methods and environments. Rather than being trained to execute a specific analysis one way, course material will promote self-directed learning and exploration of different tools and methods, according to the background and prior knowledge of each student.

SUBMISSION: Moodle quizzes and LabArchives assignments.

ASSESSMENT: Students will demonstrate understanding of core concepts and competency in basic tasks through a series of Moodle quizzes and LabArchives assignments.

FEEDBACK: Each practical is set up as a Moodle lession with embedded formative quizzes. Additional formative feedback is given to students in prac classes, through interactions with instructors and demonstrators. Grades are released via Moodle and an in-class discussion will highlight recurring errors and misconceptions that should be corrected for the second part of the prac.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"25e7a17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e5e7a17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619cd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"99e7a17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ab","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This assessment is a written exam requiring knowledge acquired in lectures given throughout the term. Students will be asked to answer one question from each of three sections:  

  1. Genes and Genomics (Weeks 1-2)
  2. Molecular Evolution (Weeks 4-5)
  3. Applications of Genomics (Weeks 8-9)

Mark/grade will be released to students on official assessment results release date. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a9e7a17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ca","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"ade7a17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e5e7a17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619cd","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d1e7a17bdbbd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Bioinformatics Genomics Practical","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"25","description":"

AIM: Learn how to perform, manage and write up analysis of real data using real bioinformatics tools.

TASK: The main coursework for BABS3291 is a term-long online bioinformatics practical, supported by computer labs and Moodle lessons. In the first part of the practical, students will work through step-by-step guides to different molecular evolution analyses (Assessment 2). In the second half of the prac, students will apply their learning to the analysis of a protein-coding gene of their choice. Emphasis throughout the project will be on transferable bioinformatics skills and exposure to a variety of potential methods and environments. Rather than being trained to execute a specific analysis one way, course material will promote self-directed learning and exploration of different tools and methods, according to the background and prior knowledge of each student.

SUBMISSION: Submission will be as a single document via Turnitin assignment on Moodle.

ASSESSMENT: Students will submit a single project report describing the analyses they have chosen to perform. Suggested analyses are provided during the practical session. Marks will be awarded for presentation, adherence to formatting instructions, clarity and precision of methods, quality of figures, and scientific insight. Grading is rubric-guided.

FEEDBACK: Report marks are released to students via Moodle on an official release date. Formative feedback is given to students during development of the material in prac classes, through interaction with instructors and demonstrators.

contentlets.keywords: biotechnology & biomolecular sciences,biotechnology and biomolecular science
contentlets.description: This course covers cutting edge concepts in genetics, genomics and evolution: genome structure (how genes are organised into genomes), genomics (genome sequencing, assembly and annotation), genome variation and the forces that shape it (mutation, recombination and genetic drift), molecular phylogenetics (capturing and using patterns of evolution), and applications of genomics (conservation genomics, host-pathogen interactions, genome engineering, and systems biology). Multiple aspects of genome biology will be studied and integrated to understand how genomes function and evolve. Core concepts and methods in genomics, molecular evolution and population genetics will be supported by an integrated set of tutorials, science communication tasks and bioinformatics analysis. Modern research methods will be applied to the study and annotation of draft genome assemblies for two venomous Australian snakes (the mainland tiger snake and eastern brown snake), which were sequenced by UNSW at the Ramaciotti Centre for Genomics using the latest sequencing technologies.
contentlets.title: Genes, Genomes and Evolution

This course is designed to introduce students to research methodology, and to stimulate critical and lateral thinking in the context of problem solving. The course involves directed reading, laboratory work and use of internet resources. Students work on a research project under the supervision of a member of the academic staff. 


Enrolment in this course is by invitation and is based on academic performance. Interested students should contact the course coordinator or the BSB Student Office (BABStudent@unsw.edu.au). 


Note: This course is restricted to students who have completed 48 units of credit, have a WAM of 75 or more and are enrolled in a Biotechnology, Bioinformatics, Genetics, Microbiology or Molecular and Cell Biology major in one of the following programs*:


Bachelor of Science


Bachelor of Advanced Science


Bachelor of Medical Science


*including associated dual degree programs.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c2cb52afdb799850eb6b147a3a961935","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Performance in the lab","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

This is ongoing and students will be required to submit their lab books in week 11. Feedback will be provided to students within 1 week of submission by the project supervisor. 

Students will be assessed with the following criteria:

  • Safe and competent laboratory practices
  • Efficient time management
  • Active input/discussion of experimental design and interpretation of results
  • Timely, clear and professional upkeep of laboratory workbook

Feedback will be provided by the course coordinator and released within 1 week of submission.

Biotechnology & Bioengineering Advanced","description":"

In order to bring new biotechnology products to the market, scalable bioprocesses must be developed and validated. This course covers the bioprocessing and economic principles involved in the operation, development and design of large scale biotechnology-based processes. It includes analysis of fermentation kinetics, batch and continuous modes of operation, bioprocess optimisation, principles of fermentor scale up, downstream processing and bioprocess design, as well as principles of economic feasibility analysis. Selected bioprocesses will be used to develop an understanding of fundamental bioprocessing principles, including process scale-up. Examples will be drawn from major biotechnology sectors, including biofuels, biopharmaceutical manufacture and manufacture of other bioproducts from bacterial, yeast and mammalian hosts. Laboratory sessions and problem solving tutorials (including computer based classes)will supplement lecture material. At least one detailed case study will be undertaken by students which will investigate economic and technical feasibility of a bioprocess.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"ecf3aa27dbf99850eb6b147a3a96192f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

This examination consists of quantitative and qualitative questions which will cover materials delivered in weeks 5-10. 

Mark/grade will be released to students on official assessment results release date. Feedback will be provided upon request.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"2cf3aa27dbf99850eb6b147a3a961923","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"a4f3aa27dbf99850eb6b147a3a961929","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ecf3aa27dbf99850eb6b147a3a961920","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"18f3aa27dbf99850eb6b147a3a961917","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Major Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"16","description":"

There are two parts to this assignment: 

  1. Define the biorefinery concept 
  2. Understand and Explain one of the biorefinery concepts given in part 1

Full detail will be provided in the course manual and (or) Moodle site. 

The course convenor will mark this assignment and written feedback will be returned to students. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"68f3aa27dbf99850eb6b147a3a961926","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"a4f3aa27dbf99850eb6b147a3a961929","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"94f36a27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619fd","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Laboratory Work - Report*","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"24","description":"

This assignment will be in the format of a scientific paper (full detail will be available in the course manual or Moodle site). 

*BABS3631 students will undertake an extra project to be discussed with the Course Convenor. They will do a small lab project and write a short report. The marks for this extra work will be added to the marks above and then normalised to a mark out of 100.

The course convenor will mark this assignment and written feedback will be provided.

This test will consist of both quantitative and qualitative questions on syllabus topics. The test will cover material presented in weeks 1-5. 

Mark will be released online in Moodle. The solutions will be visited in class.

Students in program 3052 (BSc Biotechnology), who qualify for the 4th year by obtaining a credit average or greater in their Stage 3 courses, will complete their training by undertaking full-time research in the fourth year, enrolling in BABS4053. Students will work within a supervised laboratory environment on an independent research project, designing, performing and interpreting experiments. A written thesis on this research is prepared by the student and submitted. The assessment will be based on the research thesis and performance in the final seminar. The course also includes formative assessment in terms of a submitted literature review, a practice thesis and practice seminar to assist the development of skills in research communication.

Prerequisites: Completion of all requirements for stages 1, 2, and 3 of the 3052 program (144UOC). A credit average in Stage 3 courses is required for entry.

A 16 UOC Research Project in the School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences, taken in three trimesters providing a total of 48 UOC. This course is only available to students enrolled in an Honours Program in the School of BABS and enrolment must be approved by the School of BABS Honours Coordinator. The course entails research in a defined disciplinary area (Biotechnology, Genetics, Microbiology, Molecular and Cell Biology) developed in consultation with an Honours Supervisor.


This course is only available to students enrolled in the School of BABS Honours Program.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"7cb10977db391c50eb6b147a3a9619e3","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Thesis","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"90","description":"

The written thesis should follow the format for a Masters or Ph.D. thesis, but will be shorter; the thesis should not exceed 70 pages (references, figures and tables are not included in the limit).  There must be a title page, a table of contents, a list of figures and tables, and an abstract all preceding the main body of text. The main body of the text must be comprised of sections including an Introduction, Methods and Materials, Results, and Discussion. Figures, tables, references and abbreviations should follow the general form of a scientific paper written for, for example, Journal of Biological Chemistry, Journal of Bacteriology, or the Journal of Immunology. 


Each student will have their thesis critically assessed internally by at least three reviewers.  Each member of the student's committee

will then independently read and assess the final thesis without consultation with each other. After meeting with the student in

the final thesis interview, the student will be excused and the committee will come to an agreement on the final mark for thesis. If

there is a discrepancy and the committee cannot come to an agreement on the final mark, then a fourth examiner can be called for to

provide another independent assessment of the thesis. Once determined by the Assessment committee, the final Honours

mark for all students in a given cohort will be discussed at a School assessment review meeting.

These marks are then submitted to the Faculty of Science for final review before release to the students.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"20b10977db391c50eb6b147a3a9619ce","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a4b10977db391c50eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e0b10977db391c50eb6b147a3a9619cb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"18b10977db391c50eb6b147a3a9619b2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Seminar","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Students will be required to present a seminar on outcomes of their research project to date; 20 minutes are allocated for speaking with 5 minutes for questions.
Students are graded by the academics in the audience, and their final average mark (out of 5%) is given to the student. Students are also provided with oral feedback from their supervisor in terms of presentation style to assist them in future presentations.

contentlets.description:
A 16 UOC Research Project in the School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Sciences, taken in three trimesters providing a total of 48 UOC. This course is only available to students enrolled in an Honours Program in the School of BABS and enrolment must be approved by the School of BABS Honours Coordinator. The course entails research in a defined disciplinary area (Biotechnology, Genetics, Microbiology, Molecular and Cell Biology) developed in consultation with an Honours Supervisor.

This course is only available to students enrolled in the School of BABS Honours Program.

This is one of the courses used to comprise the 30 UOC research project under the supervision of an academic in the School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Science to fulfil the requirements of a Biotechnology and Biomolecular Science stream in the Graduate Diploma (Research) program.


All students have a supervisor and are assigned an examiner by the Postgraduate Coordinator in BABS. In their first term students will submit a literature review to their supervisor for feedback on their writing and critique of the available literature. Students are then expected to present a seminar and submit a written thesis at the completion of their project. The thesis will contribute 75%, the seminar will contribute 5% and the average of the three course work subjects taken contribute 20% of the final mark.  


This course is only available to students enrolled into the Biotechnology and Biomolecular Science stream of the Graduate Diploma (Research) in the Faculty of Science.

contentlets.description:
This is one of the courses used to comprise the 30 UOC research project under the supervision of an academic in the School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Science to fulfil the requirements of a Biotechnology and Biomolecular Science stream in the Graduate Diploma (Research) program.

All students have a supervisor and are assigned an examiner by the Postgraduate Coordinator in BABS. In their first term students will submit a literature review to their supervisor for feedback on their writing and critique of the available literature. Students are then expected to present a seminar and submit a written thesis at the completion of their project. The thesis will contribute 75%, the seminar will contribute 5% and the average of the three course work subjects taken contribute 20% of the final mark.  

This course is only available to students enrolled into the Biotechnology and Biomolecular Science stream of the Graduate Diploma (Research) in the Faculty of Science.

This is one of the courses used to comprise the 30 UOC research project under the supervision of an academic in the School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Science to fulfil the requirements of a Biotechnology and Biomolecular Science stream in the Graduate Diploma (Research) program.


All students have a supervisor and are assigned an examiner by the Postgraduate Coordinator in BABS. In their first term students will submit a literature review to their supervisor for feedback on their writing and critique of the available literature. Students are then expected to present a seminar and submit a written thesis at the completion of their project. The thesis will contribute 75%, the seminar will contribute 5% and the average of the three course work subjects taken contribute 20% of the final mark.  


This course is only available to students enrolled into the Biotechnology and Biomolecular Science stream of the Graduate Diploma (Research) in the Faculty of Science.

contentlets.description:
This is one of the courses used to comprise the 30 UOC research project under the supervision of an academic in the School of Biotechnology and Biomolecular Science to fulfil the requirements of a Biotechnology and Biomolecular Science stream in the Graduate Diploma (Research) program.

All students have a supervisor and are assigned an examiner by the Postgraduate Coordinator in BABS. In their first term students will submit a literature review to their supervisor for feedback on their writing and critique of the available literature. Students are then expected to present a seminar and submit a written thesis at the completion of their project. The thesis will contribute 75%, the seminar will contribute 5% and the average of the three course work subjects taken contribute 20% of the final mark.  

This course is only available to students enrolled into the Biotechnology and Biomolecular Science stream of the Graduate Diploma (Research) in the Faculty of Science.

Students are introduced to the issues and challenges facing leaders of public and private sector organizations, and communities seeking to achieve shared goals within the global biotechnology industry, The course brings together diverse academic science and business disciplines (science, regulatory affairs, marketing, finance, legal, ethics, communication, and intellectual property management). It explores how these disciplines can be used as powerful tools to create effective leadership, and productive collaborations within the global industry, while improving managerial decision making. The course provides an overview of the global industry, its infrastructure, and the barriers and opportunities with specific attention to the US, European Australasian and Asian markets.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"71ea2173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619fd","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critical review","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This assessment task aims to assess the ability to research relevant information on business topics that may impact biotechnology companies. Students will be required to locate a recent business article in a peer-reviewed journal or a reputable business publication or newspaper. They will then identify business issues discussed in the article, review them and discuss the significance of these issues in relation to the sustainability and profitability of biotechnology companies.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"61ea2173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ee","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6dea2173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619de","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"adea2173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e9ea2173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"95ea2173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619b3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Weekly learning activities","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

Students will be expected to participate in weekly learning activities, including quizzes (individual, 25%) and discussions and engage in regular reviews (when not providing peer review feedback for Business Analysis Report), analysis, discussion and reflection (group, 10%).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"29ea2173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"61ea2173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619ee","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"65ea2173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"6dea2173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619de","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"adea2173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e9ea2173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619f3","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"95ea2173dbfd1c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Business Analysis Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"45","description":"

This assessment task aims to develop the skills to identify and evaluate how global biotechnology companies successfully access global markets in both Australasia and the US. Student teams (4 members) will choose a publicly listed biotechnology company of their collective interest that has successfully commercialised globally biotechnology related products.  The teams will explore the company’s history from foundation by analysing its business strategy in terms of product and technology development (including pipelines), intellectual property management, funding, manufacturing, business model, regulation,  competitive advantage and its approach to accessing and distributing in key global markets. Teams will prepare a written report on their investigation’s findings which will include a SWOT analysis that critiques aspects of the company’s business and commercialisation strategy that has led to its success and makes recommendations that the company could adopt to enhance and secure its future potential. As part of this assessment task, students will learn to share leadership roles, and will contribute to ongoing asynchronous discussions. They will also learn to provide, and respond to, critical and constructive peer review feedback both within their team and with other teams in the class.

(Breakdown of assessment: Teamwork, comprising a written report – 20%; individual, oral presentation – 15% and peer-review feedback – 10%)

It explores how these disciplines can be used as powerful tools to create effective leadership, and productive collaborations within the global industry, while improving managerial decision making. The course provides an overview of the global industry, its infrastructure, and the barriers and opportunities with specific attention to the US, European Australasian and Asian markets.

They will also learn to provide, and respond to, critical and constructive peer review feedback both within their team and with other teams in the class.

(Breakdown of assessment: Teamwork, comprising a written report – 20%; individual, oral presentation – 15% and peer-review feedback – 10%)

contentlets.description: Students are introduced to the issues and challenges facing leaders of public and private sector organizations, and communities seeking to achieve shared goals within the global biotechnology industry, The course brings together diverse academic science and business disciplines (science, regulatory affairs, marketing, finance, legal, ethics, communication, and intellectual property management). It explores how these disciplines can be used as powerful tools to create effective leadership, and productive collaborations within the global industry, while improving managerial decision making. The course provides an overview of the global industry, its infrastructure, and the barriers and opportunities with specific attention to the US, European Australasian and Asian markets.
contentlets.title: Introduction to Biotechnology Commercialisation
